prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Field setup: A single pointing for each galaxy is sufficient to cover the CO extent. The galaxies are grouped by 10 deg (4-6 members), and the velocities are within 4000 km/s so that they can share calibration.
Spectral setup: We need just one spectral window covering the CO(1-0) line of all the galaxies in the group. We added another spectral window next to it to make sure that we do not miss part of the line of the most redshifted galaxies.
Calibration: Standard Calibration is sufficient.
Control and performance:
-Array We will use a single 12m array configuration with longest bsln ~ 0.32 km, which corresponds to a synthesized beam of ~1.6", enough to ensure angular resolutions better than 750 pc. No ACA is needed, as emission extent for each individual channel of 20 km/s is likely ~10" or less, depending on the inclination of the galaxy, and maximum angular scale is about 20".
-Sensitivity Estimate: We estimate the CO luminosities, L'co, from the SFR (derived from SDSS data, see Science Justificatioin) and the Kennicutt-Schmidt law. The expected flux density is Sco = 3.08 x 10-8 L'co nu_rest**2 (1+z) / (DeltaV_rest D_L^2), where nu_rest=115 GHz, D_L is the luminosity distance, DeltaV_rest the velocity width and z the redshift. We use the relation logLFIR = 1.7 logL'CO -5.0 (Gao & Solomon 2004), and log(SFR(Msun yr-1)) = log(2.2 x 10^10 LFIR(Lsun)) (Lisenfeld et al. 2011), so that logL'CO = (10-log(2.2) +log(SFR(Msun yr-1)) +5 )/1.7. We choose sigma = 2 mJy/beam to have S/N > 5 in all galaxies (note that it is S/N>20 in 84% of the galaxies).
The Sigma_H2 = 20 Msun pc-2 in a face- on spiral galaxy. To translate CO intensity, ICO , into molecular gas surface density, Sigma_H2, we apply Sigma_H2 = [Msun pc-2]= 5.5 Ico [K kms -1] cos i where we assume a CO to H2 conversion factor of 2 x 10 20 cm-2 (K km s-1 )-1 , Sigma_H2 = 20 Msun pc-2 traces gas where the ISM is dominated by H2 rather than HI. The sensitivity limit and the resolution of 750 pc correspond to a H2 mass sensitivity of ~ 10**7 Msun , which would be sufficient to detect Galactic Giant Molecular Associations (e.g. Blitz 1993). The total observing time to achieve Sigma_gas ~20 Msun pc-2 per galaxy is ~6 min.
Note that the uncertainty in the conversion factor is large, and can be a factor 2-3 different for the Z range between 8.4 and 9.2 (Leroy et al. 2011). However, we will detect most of the galaxies even in the worst case scenario (>84%).
For the peak line flux we assume an average based on the Lco estimate. The line widths are based on HI line widths.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We aim to unveil the molecular gas properties of galaxies evolving secularly, in an equilibrium between gas inflow, outflow and star formation. We will investigate the fundamental relations between molecular gas, atomic gas, stellar mass, star formation rate, and metallicity, with minimized contamination due to the effect of the environment, and emphasizing the poorly studied range of low stellar masses (log(M_*[Msun])<10.0) and low star formation rates (log(SFR[Msun/yr])<0.5) which characterize the vast majority of isolated late type spirals. The sample we have chosen is composed of 50 nearby galaxies proven to be isolated based on SDSS DR9 photometric and spectroscopic information, and covering the parameter space of this population of isolated spirals. The modest request of observing time (10 hours) in band 3 will also allow us, for the first time, to study the distribution and kinematics of the bulk of the molecular gas using CO J=1-0 emission, with resolutions <750 pc, and surface density sensitivities Sigma_gas ~ 20 Msun pc-2. This will allow us to investigate the link between the molecular gas distribution and the location of each galaxy in the fundamental relations.
